labInfo.name: Keating Lab
labInfo.tagline: Unlocking the Future of Transplant Medicine.
labInfo.description: Welcome to the Keating Lab! We are a research group dedicated to advancing the field of transplantation medicine through multiomic science. Our work delves deep into the intricate  molecular mechanisms of genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics and integrating these powerful datasets to understand the biology of transplant biology through different molecular lenses. By integrating advanced immunology with insights from molecular pathology and the innovative application of artificial intelligence (AI), we aim to decipher the molecular underpinnings of transplant outcomes, ultimately striving to enhance patient outcomes and usher in a new era of personalized, precision medicine.
labInfo.address: NYU Langone Health, 550 First Ave, New York, NY 10016
labInfo.contactDescription: Reach out to us for inquiries, collaboration opportunities, or to learn more about our work.

researchProjects.title: Organ Transplantation & Xenotransplantation - Improving Transplant Outcomes: From Allografts to Xenografts.
researchProjects.description: Our lab is deeply committed to advancing the field of organ transplantation, focusing on both conventional allograft (human-to-human) procedures and the groundbreaking frontier of xenotransplantation (pig-to-human). A significant area of our research centers on kidney and heart xenotransplantation, where we meticulously analyze the complex immune responses and cellular dynamics in pig-to-human models. We employ longitudinal multi-omic profiling to uncover the molecular mechanisms of rejection and acceptance, aiming to develop novel strategies that enhance transplant success and to understand immunologic barriers in cross-species transplantation. Our work also extends to improving long-term human kidney allograft survival by exploring innovative approaches to HLA compatibility and the role of non-HLA genes.

researchProjects.title: Precision Genetics & Multi-Omics - Unlocking Biological Insights Through Genomic and Multi-Omic Profiling
researchProjects.description: At the core of our research is the application of advanced genomic and multi-omic technologies to unravel the genetic and molecular underpinnings of disease and transplant outcomes. We use comprehensive approaches such as whole genome sequencing for family-based rare variant association analysis, as exemplified by our studies in rare and common diseases impacting end-stage disease precipitating transplantation, to identify novel genetic determinants. Furthermore, our lab specializes in integrative multi-omics profiling, combining data from genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics to provide a holistic view of biological systems. This allows us to gain unprecedented insights into the intricate molecular responses in various biological contexts, including the detailed analysis of host-graft interactions in transplantation.

researchProjects.title: Immunogenetics & Transplant Compatibility - Optimizing Compatibility: Immunogenetics, Equity, and Rejection Pathology
researchProjects.description: A critical aspect of successful transplantation lies in understanding and optimizing immunologic compatibility. Our lab investigates immunogenetics, particularly focusing on Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) matching and the implications of eplet mismatch for deceased-donor kidney allocation. We conduct crucial research into balancing equity and maximizing compatibility, addressing racial disparities in transplant access. Beyond compatibility, we delve into the immune response post-transplantation, conducting multimodal phenotyping studies to characterize early immune responses and rejection pathology in detail, including antibody-mediated injury. These efforts are aimed at developing targeted therapeutic interventions to overcome rejection and ensure the long-term viability of transplanted organs.

funding.name: NIAID
funding.description: NIAID conducts and supports basic and applied research to better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases. For more than 60 years, NIAID research has led to new therapies, vaccines, diagnostic tests, and other technologies that have improved the health of millions of people in the United States and around the world.

funding.name: Cardiovascular Research Center (CVRC)
funding.description: The mission of the Cardiovascular Research Center (CVRC), a part of NYU Langone’s Leon H. Charney Division of Cardiology, is to foster novel, interdisciplinary research in basic, translational, and clinical cardiovascular sciences. Our researchers are investigating cardiac development and diseases ranging from congenital conditions in children to acquired illness in adult patients such as congestive heart failure, arrhythmias, and atherosclerosis.

funding.name: Department of Surgery at NYU Langone Health
funding.description: Our lab collaborates closely with the Department of Surgery at NYU Langone Health, a nationally recognized leader in surgical excellence and innovation. Together, we focus on advancing the science of transplantation through interdisciplinary research that bridges the clinic and the lab. NYU Langone’s transplant surgeons are not only at the forefront of complex organ transplantation but are also deeply committed to driving forward discoveries in immunology, organ preservation, and tissue regeneration. This partnership provides a unique environment where clinician–scientists and basic researchers work side by side to develop novel therapies that improve transplant outcomes and extend graft survival. Philanthropic support is critical to sustaining this work—enabling us to pursue high-risk, high-reward research, train future transplant researchers, and bring lifesaving innovations from bench to bedside.

collaborations.name: Brian D. Piening, PhD, Providence Health
collaborations.description: Dr. Piening is trained in genetics, genomics and bioinformatics. Along with leading the Cancer Immuno-Genomics Lab at the Earle A. Chiles Research Institute, a Providence Center of Excellence for immuno-oncology and cellular therapy, he also serves as program director of Providence Genomics. There, he uses comprehensive genomic profiling to develop personalized treatment plans for people with advanced cancer. The laboratory is one of only a handful in the world that performs whole genome sequencing in a clinical context and is the dedicated clinical sequencing facility for Providence.

collaborations.name: Mike Snyder, PhD, Stanford Medicine
collaborations.description: Snyder Lab was the first to perform a large-scale functional genomics project in any organism, and has developed many technologies in genomics and proteomics. These including the development of proteome chips, high resolution tiling arrays for the entire human genome, methods for global mapping of transcription factor binding sites (ChIP-chip now replaced by ChIP-seq), paired end sequencing for mapping of structural variation in eukaryotes, de novo genome sequencing of genomes using high throughput technologies and RNA-Seq. These technologies have been used for characterizing genomes, proteomes and regulatory networks.

collaborations.name: Jessica van Setten
collaborations.description: Jessica specializes in the complex genetics of cardiovascular diseases and traits, specifically cardiomyopathies, heart failure, heart transplantation, and ECG. She is leading multiple projects, supervising and mentoring multiple PhDs, PostDocs, and (under)graduate students.

collaborations.name: iGeneTRAiN
collaborations.description: iGeneTRAiN aims to coordinate genetic and other patient biospecimen and clinical datasets, from sites across the world engaged in clinical and research transplant programs. We are well underway in generating massive, integrated datasets that will empower us to identify factors associated with transplant success. Relevant information includes data from clinical, genetic, protein, metabolite, and a range of other studies, including wearable devices.

members.name: Francesca Zanoni
members.projects: I currently lead and coordinate several multi-center translational research projects focused on the genetic and immunological determinants of  kidney transplantation outcomes. These studies are conducted within the framework of large international consortia such as iGeneTRAiN, in close collaboration with several Research Centers. My work includes developing and applying polygenic risk scores (PRS) for IgA nephropathy, membranous nephropathy, and chronic kidney disease to predict post-transplant disease recurrence.  In addition, I conduct genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and cross-organ meta-analyses exploring the genetic architecture of acute rejection and graft failure in solid organ transplantation. Lastly, given my clinical expertise, I contribute to multi-omics allo- and xeno-transplantation studies to improve the clinical traslationability of new findings.
members.about: I am a nephrologist and academic researcher with dual clinical and research training in Italy and the United States. My primary research interest lies at the intersection of nephrology, transplantation, and genomics, with a focus on identifying genetic risk factors that can inform personalized medicine approaches in kidney transplantation and glomerular diseases. I aim to bridge the gap between genomic discoveries and clinical application to improve patient outcomes.

She received her Masters degree in Genetic Counseling at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and her Bachelors in Molecular Biology from UC Berkeley. Previously, she worked in Product Development in the sequencing biotechnology industry. While at Mount Sinai, she worked for the eMERGE network (Electronic Medical Records & Genomics) to study the use of genetic testing in the general population.

members.name: Mauricio Arcila-Mesa, M.D.
members.degree: Universidad Autónoma de Guadalajara School of Medicine
members.projects: Feasibility Study of Xofluza treatment of Influenza in Pediatric Transplant Recipients, Waitlisted Subjects and Household Members after early infection alerting using Wearable Devices.
members.about: I’m a Research Project Manager at NYU Langone, where I support clinical and translational research in transplantation. Originally from Colombia, I’m passionate about creating inclusive, collaborative research environments and helping move science forward in ways that center patients. Outside of work, I love to travel, cook, and explore the intersection of culture, health, and community.

members.name: Mercy Rophina
members.degree: I earned my Ph.D. from the CSIR-Institute of Genomics and Integrative Biology (IGIB) in New Delhi, India, with a specialization in genome informatics, population genomics, and pathogen genomics. My doctoral research was primarily focused on transfusion and transplantation genomics, where I explored genomic diversity and its implications for clinical compatibility and immune response
members.projects: I am currently involved in several genomics-focused research projects within the field of transplantation. A major component of my work involves the analysis of whole genome sequencing (WGS) data from transplant recipient cohorts, with the goal of identifying both primary pathogenic variants and secondary/incidental findings that may have clinical implications. In addition, I focus on pharmacogenomic profiling to predict individual responses to immunosuppressive and other commonly prescribed medications, which is critical for optimizing post-transplant care. My work also includes detailed typing of immune-related gene families such as HLA, KIR, and LILR, which are essential for understanding graft compatibility, rejection risk, and immune modulation. Complementing this, I lead efforts in single-cell transcriptomic analysis of xenotransplant recipients, where I investigate the composition and dynamics of urinary immune and epithelial cell populations across multiple timepoints. This allows us to track cellular and immunological changes over the course of transplantation, providing insights into graft adaptation, early rejection signals, and immune activation. In addition to these projects, I also contribute to genome-wide association studies (GWAS) across transplant and other patient cohorts to identify genetic variants associated with acute rejection, graft failure, and other post-transplant complications. Together, these efforts aim to enhance precision medicine approaches in transplantation by integrating genomic, cellular, and clinical data.
members.about: I joined Keating’s lab as a postdoctoral fellow in March 2024, and  over the past year, it’s been incredibly rewarding to apply my genomics skillset in the context of transplantation research. Working at the intersection of science and clinical care has not only deepened my appreciation for translational genomics but also given me the chance to learn a wide range of new techniques and perspectives. That ongoing sense of learning is what keeps the excitement of doing science alive for me. Outside the lab, I find joy in painting—it's my creative outlet and a grounding balance to my research life.

members.about: After starting my career in infectious disease diagnostics and surveillance in Australia, I moved to Columbia University to explore virus discovery and vector borne diseases. I have since worked in biotech building molecular diagnostic LDTs for targets including SARS-CoV-2 and monkeypox, as well as expanded qPCR panels for respiratory, lesion, fungal and gastrointestinal pathogens. Working within the xenotransplant field allows me to bring all these experiences together and apply them to an exciting new therapeutic technology.
